title: The Silk Road: Connecting the ancient world through trade - Shannon Harris Castelo

multiple-choice.question: What was the Silk Road, and how did it emerge over time?

options.label: A
options.text: A single road that was built by the ancient Chinese to connect with the West.

options.label: B
options.text: A network of multiple routes that gradually emerged over centuries, connecting to various settlements and to each other.

options.label: C
options.text: A maritime trade route that connected Europe and Asia.

options.label: D
options.text: A series of isolated agricultural civilizations that had no contact with each other.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the Persian Royal Road, completed by Darius the First in the 5th century BCE?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the first road to connect China and the West.

options.label: B
options.text: It allowed goods and messages to travel at nearly 1/10 the time it would take a single traveler.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the longest road in the ancient world.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first road to be built by the ancient Persians.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the encounter between Chinese and Roman soldiers in Central Asia?

options.label: A
options.text: The transmission of crossbow technology to the Western world.

options.label: B
options.text: The transmission of gunpowder technology to the Western world.

options.label: C
options.text: The transmission of silk production technology to the Western world.

options.label: D
options.text: The transmission of glassware production technology to the Eastern world.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Silk Road on the spread of ideas and cultures?

options.label: A
options.text: It only allowed for the exchange of goods and commodities.

options.label: B
options.text: It enabled the movement of traditions, innovations, ideologies, and languages.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on the spread of ideas and cultures.

options.label: D
options.text: It only allowed for the exchange of ideas and cultures between China and the West.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Silk Road's success, and how did it lead to its own demise?

options.label: A
options.text: The Silk Road's success led to its expansion and growth.

options.label: B
options.text: The Silk Road's success led to the development of new maritime technologies, making long land routes obsolete.

options.label: C
options.text: The Silk Road's success led to the collapse of Mongol rule.

options.label: D
options.text: The Silk Road's success led to China's withdrawal from international trade.

title: How does your brain respond to pain? - Karen D. Davis

multiple-choice.question: What is pain defined as?

options.label: A
options.text: An unpleasant sensory experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage.

options.label: B
options.text: An emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage.

options.label: C
options.text: A sensory and emotional experience associated with only actual tissue damage.

options.label: D
options.text: A sensory experience associated with only potential tissue damage.

multiple-choice.question: What are the special tissue damage-sensing nerve cells called that fire and send signals to the spinal cord and brain when you get hurt?
What is the name of the system of interconnected brain cells that decides what to pay attention to, including pain signals?
What are the chemicals released when you're in pain or during extreme exercise, creating the "runner's high"?
Why does it matter that there is variability in our pain brain circuits?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it means that some people are more sensitive to pain than others.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it means that some people respond better to certain treatments than others.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it means that some people develop chronic pain that does not respond to treatment.

title: How languages evolve - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: According to the biblical story of the Tower of Babel, what happened to humanity's language?

options.label: A
options.text: It evolved into many languages over time.

options.label: B
options.text: It suddenly split into many languages.

multiple-choice.question: What do linguists use to determine whether languages are related?

options.label: B
options.text: Grammar and syntax, as well as basic vocabulary

options.label: D
options.text: The geographic location of the speakers

multiple-choice.question: What is a language family?

options.label: A
options.text: A group of languages that are mutually unintelligible

options.label: B
options.text: A group of languages that are spoken in the same geographic region

options.label: C
options.text: A group of languages that are related and share a common ancestor

options.label: D
options.text: A group of languages that are extinct

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main problems linguists face when constructing language family trees?

options.label: A
options.text: Deciding which dialects should be considered separate languages

options.label: B
options.text: Determining the geographic origins of ancient peoples

options.label: C
options.text: Reconstructing earlier languages with no written records

options.label: D
options.text: Tracing the evolution of languages over time

multiple-choice.question: Why is the number of languages estimated to be between 3,000 and 8,000?

options.label: B
options.text: Because the definition of a language is unclear

options.label: C
options.text: Because the difference between languages and dialects is often a matter of politics and national considerations

title: A digital reimagining of Gettysburg - Anne Knowles

multiple-choice.question: Who was the Confederate general who made crucial mistakes during the Battle of Gettysburg?
What is GIS, and how was it used in the presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: GIS stands for Geographic Information Systems, and it was used to create a 3D animation of the Battle of Gettysburg.

options.label: B
options.text: GIS stands for Geographic Information Systems, and it was used to analyze the terrain and determine what Robert E. Lee could see during the battle.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: GIS stands for Graphic Illustration System, and it was used to create illustrations of the battle.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the charge led by the Confederates on the third day of the Battle of Gettysburg?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because he wanted to attack the Union line at its strongest point.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Pickett's Charge?

options.label: B
options.text: The Union army was able to hold off the Confederate charge and win the battle.

options.label: C
options.text: The charge was inconclusive, and the battle continued for several more days.

options.label: D
options.text: The charge was called off due to heavy casualties on both sides.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: How the heart actually pumps blood - Edmond Hui

multiple-choice.question: What was the general understanding of the heart's function throughout most of history?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart pumps blood throughout the body.

options.label: B
options.text: The heart filters waste from the blood.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to observe the heart's function, even in the 21st century?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart is too small to see.

options.label: B
options.text: The blood vessels are opaque, and the blood itself is opaque.

options.label: C
options.text: The heart only functions at night.

options.label: D
options.text: The heart is too complex to understand.

multiple-choice.question: What is the correct description of the circulation of blood in mammals?

options.label: A
options.text: Dual-circulation: one with blood going to the lungs and back, and another to the body and back.

options.label: B
options.text: Figure-eight circulation: blood goes from one heart pump to the lungs, back to the second heart pump, which sends it to the body, and then back to the first pump.

options.label: C
options.text: Single-circulation: blood goes from the heart to the body and back.

options.label: D
options.text: Triple-circulation: blood goes from the heart to the lungs, then to the body, and then back to the heart.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of cutting off the atria and trimming them down to the tops of the ventricles in the experiment described?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the heart look more complicated.

options.label: B
options.text: To make the heart pump more efficiently.

options.label: C
options.text: To simplify the heart's structure and make it easier to observe the pumping mechanism.

options.label: D
options.text: To stop the heart from pumping altogether.

multiple-choice.question: What is observed when the ventricle is squeezed in the experiment described?

options.label: B
options.text: The ventricular valve tries to close, but leaks water.

options.label: C
options.text: The ventricular valve closes, and a stream of water squirts out of the pulmonary artery.

title: Lessons from Auschwitz: The power of our words - Benjamin Zander

multiple-choice.question: At what age did the woman's brother go to Auschwitz?
What was the last thing the woman said to her brother?

options.label: B
options.text: "Why are you so stupid? Can't you keep your things together?"

multiple-choice.question: What was the vow the woman made after coming out of Auschwitz?

options.label: A
options.text: To always speak her mind, no matter what.

options.label: B
options.text: To never say anything that couldn't stand as the last thing she ever says.

options.label: C
options.text: To always be kind to strangers.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Why did the woman make this vow?

options.label: C

options.text: Because she was trying to forget her past.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main lesson or message from the woman's story?

options.label: B
options.text: That we should always speak our minds, no matter what.

options.label: C
options.text: That our words have power and we should choose them carefully.

options.label: D

options.label: D
options.text: The trajectory of the Earth's orbit

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of sharing tours of the universe with other planetariums and classrooms, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: To show the beauty of the universe

options.label: B
options.text: To educate people about the universe

options.label: C
options.text: To help people understand where they are in the universe

title: History vs. Andrew Jackson - James Fester

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the seventh President of the United States who was both deified and vilified in his lifetime?
What was the name of the act signed by President Jackson that led to the forced removal of entire tribes from their native lands?
What was the name of the bank that President Jackson vetoed the reauthorization of in 1832, leading to the financial Panic of 1837?
What was the name of the brutal march that the Cherokee people were forced to undertake after being removed from their lands?
Who was the President who enforced the Indian Removal Act after President Jackson left office?
